sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Most mature terminal emulators permit users to copy or save their contents.

sections.title: General approach
sections.content: In graphical terminal emulators, contents are typically selectable by mouse, and can then be copied using the context menu, Edit menu or a key combination such as Ctrl+Shift+c.

sections.title: Xorg
sections.content:
Some emulators do not support the CLIPBOARD selection natively, and copy data to the PRIMARY selection. For them xclip may be used:

```
$ xclip -o | xclip -selection clipboard -i
```

The above command reads data from the PRIMARY selection and writes it to CLIPBOARD selection.

Other clipboard managers such as autocutselAUR provide automatic synchronization between selection buffers.

sections.title: Wayland
sections.content:
Utilities like wl-clipboard and clipboardAUR can copy data to the Wayland clipboard:

```
$ command 2>&1 | wl-copy
```

sections.title: Intercepting commands output
sections.content:
Use tee to intercept the output of a command.

```
$ command 2>&1 | tee output-file
```

After the command is executed, output-file will contain its output, while having displayed the output at the same time.

sections.title: Accessing Linux terminal backlog
sections.content:
The backlog of a native terminal named /dev/ttyN may be accessed via /dev/vcsN. Hence, if one is working in /dev/tty1, the following snippet will let store the backlog in a file output-file:

```
# cat /dev/vcs1 > output-file
```

sections.title: putty
sections.content: The xclip approach works for putty: one just has to remember that the xclip invocation should be done on the local computer (in another terminal), not on the remote machine to which putty is connected.

sections.title: urxvt
sections.content: Selecting text to CLIPBOARD requires the selection-to-clipboard perl extension. See rxvt-unicode#Clipboard for details.

sections.title: xterm
sections.content: Access to the CLIPBOARD selection in xterm requires additional steps.

sections.title: mlterm
sections.content: In addition to Ctrl+Shift+c, you can use Ctrl+Insert if you do not want to kill processes accidentally.
